alert.note: Alert for King (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 12 at 2:35PM PST until January 14 at 2:09AM PST by NWS Seattle
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Washington... Snoqualmie River Near Carnation affecting King County. Snoqualmie River Near Snoqualmie Falls affecting King County. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Washington... Skykomish River Near Gold Bar affecting Snohomish County. .Heavy rain in the central Cascades has ceased this afternoon. While the Skykomish is near its crest, the Snoqualmie while continue to rise tonight as the flood wave moves downstream. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT FROM THIS AFTERNOON THROUGH LATE THURSDAY NIGHT... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Snoqualmie River Near Carnation. * WHEN...Until early Friday morning. * IMPACTS...At 56.0 feet, the Snoqualmie River will cause widespread flooding from Fall City downstream through Carnation and Duvall... inundating much of the farm land and numerous roads. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1:00 PM PST Wednesday the stage was 54.7 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 1:00 PM PST Wednesday was 54.7 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 58.0 feet late this evening. It will then fall below flood stage early tomorrow afternoon. - Flood stage is 54.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 58.0 feet on 11/09/1995. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. Most flood related deaths occur in automobiles. Do not attempt to cross water covered bridges, dips, or low water crossings. Never try to cross a flowing stream, even a small one, on foot. To escape rising water find another route over higher ground. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued by this evening at 1030 PM PST.
